message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Collaborative Multi-Robot Search and Rescue: Planning, Coordination, Perception, and Active Vision
Paper Abstract: Search and rescue (SAR) operations can take significant advantage from supporting autonomous or teleoperated robots and multi-robot systems. These can aid in mapping and situational assessment, monitoring and surveillance, establishing communication networks, or searching for victims. This paper provides a review of multi-robot systems supporting SAR operations, with system-level considerations and focusing on the algorithmic perspectives for multi-robot coordination and perception. This is, to the best of our knowledge, the first survey paper to cover (i) heterogeneous SAR robots in different environments, (ii) active perception in multi-robot systems, while (iii) giving two complementary points of view from the multi-agent perception and control perspectives. We also discuss the most significant open research questions: shared autonomy, sim-to-real transferability of existing methods, awareness of victims' conditions, coordination and interoperability in heterogeneous multi-robot systems, and active perception. The different topics in the survey are put in the context of the different challenges and constraints that various types of robots (ground, aerial, surface, or underwater) encounter in different SAR environments (maritime, urban, wilderness, or other post-disaster scenarios). The objective of this survey is to serve as an entry point to the various aspects of multi-robot SAR systems to researchers in both the machine learning and control fields by giving a global overview of the main approaches being taken in the SAR robotics area.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the web search results, here's information about active perception:

## Definition

Active perception is the selecting of behaviors to increase information from the flow of data those behaviors produce in a particular environment. More specifically, to understand the world, we move around and explore it—sampling the world through our senses to construct an understanding (perception) of the environment on the basis of that behavior (action).

## Key Characteristics

Within the construct of active perception, interpretation of sensory data is inherently inseparable from the behaviors required to capture that data, and action and perception are tightly coupled.

## Applications

Active perception has been developed most comprehensively with respect to vision (active vision) where an agent (animal, robot, human, camera mount) changes position to improve the view of a specific object, or where an agent uses movement to perceive the environment (e.g., a robot avoiding obstacles).(no content)There is a wide range of work on the application of active perception to robotics, including ground vehicles, underwater vehicles, and air vehicles.

## Theoretical Context

Active perception is part of the broader field of ecological psychology, which was formulated by gestalt psychologists in the 1930s, and refined by Gibson through the 1950s to 1970s.

Here are the search results for "Autonomous robot":

## Overview

An autonomous robot is a robot that acts without recourse to human control.(no content)Historic examples include space probes, while modern examples include self-driving vacuums and cars.

## Types and Applications

Autonomous robots are used in various domains:

- **Domestic Applications**: A new area showing commercial promise is domestic robots, with a flood of small vacuuming robots beginning with iRobot and Electrolux in 2002.

- **Delivery Services**: A delivery robot is an autonomous robot that provides "last mile" delivery services.(no content)Delivery robots can be used in different settings such as food delivery, package delivery, hospital delivery, and room service.

- **Security and Monitoring**: Amazon launched its Astro for home monitoring, security and eldercare in September 2021.

## Key Technologies

Autonomous robots must have a range of environmental sensors to perform their task and stay out of trouble.(no content)The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation.

This search provides comprehensive information about autonomous robots, their various applications, and the technologies that enable them to function independently.

Links: [{"title":"Search and rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_and_rescue"},{"title":"RAF Search and Rescue Force - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RAF_Search_and_Rescue_Force"},{"title":"Combat search and rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combat_search_and_rescue"},{"title":"Urban search and rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urban_search_and_rescue"},{"title":"Mounted search and rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mounted_search_and_rescue"},{"title":"National Search and Rescue Agency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Search_and_Rescue_Agency"},{"title":"Search and rescue dog - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_and_rescue_dog"},{"title":"National Association for Search and Rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Association_for_Search_and_Rescue"},{"title":"Storm Search and Rescue Tactical Vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storm_Search_and_Rescue_Tactical_Vehicle"},{"title":"Canadian Armed Forces Search and Rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_Armed_Forces_Search_and_Rescue"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about search and rescue:

## Overview

Search and rescue (SAR) is the search for and provision of aid to people who are in distress or imminent danger.(no content)The general field of search and rescue includes many specialty sub-fields, typically determined by the type of terrain the search is conducted over.

## Types of Search and Rescue Operations

Search and rescue encompasses various specialized domains:

- **Urban Search and Rescue (USAR)**: A type of technical rescue operation that involves the location, extrication, and initial medical stabilization of victims trapped in an urban area, namely structural collapse due to natural disasters, war, terrorism or accidents, mines and collapsed trenches.

- **Combat Search and Rescue (CSAR)**: Search and rescue operations that are carried out during war that are within or near combat zones.

- **Mounted Search and Rescue (MSAR)**: A specialty within search and rescue (SAR), using horses as search partners and for transportation to search for missing persons.

## Search and Rescue Dogs

A search-and-rescue (SAR) dog is a dog trained to respond to crime scenes, accidents, missing persons events, as well as natural or man-made disasters.(no content)Common dog breeds used for search-and-rescue work include German Shepherds, Labrador Retriever, Border Collies and Golden Retriever.

## International Operations

Different countries organize their SAR operations differently. For example, the Royal Canadian Navy (RCN) and Royal Canadian Air Force (RCAF) are jointly responsible for Canada's SAR operations.

## Search Results for "Multi-robot systems"

I've found comprehensive information about multi-robot systems from the web search. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Overview

Swarm robotics is the study of how to design independent systems of robots without centralized control, where the emerging swarming behavior is created through interactions between individual robots and the environment.(no content)Swarm robotic platforms apply swarm robotics in multi-robot collaboration, with the main goal of controlling a large number of robots (with limited sensing/processing ability) to accomplish a common task or problem.

### Key Characteristics

The design of swarm robotics systems is guided by swarm intelligence principles, which promote fault tolerance, scalability, and flexibility.(no content)Important principles include: robots being autonomous, capable of interacting with surroundings and providing feedback, possessing local perceiving and communicating capabilities, not exploiting centralized control or global knowledge, and cooperating with each other to accomplish tasks.

### Applications and Examples

One of the first international projects regarding swarm robotics was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005, which studied swarm behaviors such as collective transport, area coverage, and searching for objects.(no content)Progress has been made in the application of autonomous swarms in manufacturing, known as swarm 3D printing, which is particularly useful for the production of large structures where traditional 3D printing cannot be utilized due to hardware size constraints.

### Related Concepts

Multi-agent systems are computerized systems composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents that can solve problems difficult or impossible for an individual agent or monolithic system to solve.

Web search results for query: "Robot mapping"

Links: [{"title":"Robotic mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_mapping"},{"title":"Simultaneous localization and mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simultaneous_localization_and_mapping"},{"title":"Intelligent Robotics Group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_Robotics_Group"},{"title":"Exploration problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exploration_problem"},{"title":"Occupancy grid mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occupancy_grid_mapping"},{"title":"Serial manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serial_manipulator"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Robotics_Laboratory_at_IISc"},{"title":"Singular matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?redirect=no&title=Singular_matrix"},{"title":"3D Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3D_Robotics"},{"title":"Product of exponentials formula - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Product_of_exponentials_formula"}]

## Search Results for "Robot Mapping"

Here's a comprehensive overview of robot mapping based on the search results:

### Definition and Overview

Robotic mapping is a discipline related to computer vision and cartography.(no content)The goal for an autonomous robot is to be able to construct (or use) a map (outdoor use) or floor plan (indoor use) and to localize itself and its recharging bases or beacons in it.

### Key Techniques and Approaches

**Sensors and Data Collection:**
The allothetic source corresponds to the sensors of the robot, like a camera, a microphone, laser, lidar, or sonar.(no content)3-dimensional models of a robot's environment can be generated using range imaging sensors or 3D scanners.

**Map Representations:**
The internal representation of the map can be "metric" or "topological": The metric framework is the most common for humans and considers a two-dimensional space in which it places the objects. The objects are placed with precise coordinates. The topological framework only considers places and relations between them.

**Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM):**
The problem of errors in localization being incorporated into the map is commonly referred to as Simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM).(no content)SLAM is the computational problem of constructing or updating a map of an unknown environment while simultaneously keeping track of an agent's location within it.

**Occupancy Grid Mapping:**
Occupancy Grid Mapping refers to a family of computer algorithms in probabilistic robotics for mobile robots which address the problem of generating maps from noisy and uncertain sensor measurement data, with the assumption that the robot pose is known.

### Applications

The exploration problem arises in robotic mapping and search & rescue situations, where an environment might be dangerous or inaccessible to humans.

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Talk:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of multi-agent systems:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.

## Key Capabilities and Benefits

Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Components and Characteristics

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment, typically referring to software agents, though the agents could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Key characteristics of agents in a multi-agent system include autonomy (agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous) and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).

## Communication and Coordination

When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language, within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, this approach may lead to common improvement, with example languages being Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Talk:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of multi-agent systems:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.

## Key Capabilities and Benefits

Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Components and Characteristics

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment, typically referring to software agents, though the agents could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Key characteristics of agents in a multi-agent system include autonomy (agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous) and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).

## Communication and Coordination

When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language, within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, this approach may lead to common improvement, with example languages being Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

Links: [{"title":"Simultaneous localization and mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simultaneous_localization_and_mapping"},{"title":"Wikitude - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikitude"},{"title":"Talk:Simultaneous localization and mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Simultaneous_localization_and_mapping"},{"title":"List of SLAM methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_SLAM_Methods"},{"title":"Structure from motion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structure_from_motion"},{"title":"Intrinsic localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intrinsic_localization"},{"title":"SEIF SLAM - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SEIF_SLAM"},{"title":"Motion estimation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_estimation"},{"title":"Indoor positioning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indoor_navigation"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Robotics_Laboratory_at_IISc"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Simultaneous Localization and Mapping:

## Overview

Simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) is the computational problem of constructing or updating a map of an unknown environment while simultaneously keeping track of an agent's location within it.(no content)There are several algorithms known to solve it in, at least approximately, tractable time for certain environments.

## Solution Methods

Popular approximate solution methods include the particle filter, extended Kalman filter, covariance intersection, and GraphSLAM.

## Applications

SLAM algorithms are based on concepts in computational geometry and computer vision, and are used in robot navigation, robotic mapping and odometry for virtual reality or augmented reality.(no content)Published approaches are employed in self-driving cars, unmanned aerial vehicles, autonomous underwater vehicles, planetary rovers, newer domestic robots, and other systems.

## Types of SLAM

Since the invention of local features, such as SIFT, there has been intense research into visual SLAM (VSLAM) using primarily visual (camera) sensors, because of the increasing ubiquity of cameras such as those in mobile devices.(no content)Other recent forms of SLAM include tactile SLAM (sensing by local touch only), radar SLAM, acoustic SLAM, and Wi-Fi-SLAM (sensing by strengths of nearby Wi-Fi access points).

## History

The acronym SLAM was coined within the paper, "Localization of Autonomous Guided Vehicles" which first appeared in ISR in 1995.

Links: [{"title":"Teleoperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teleoperation"},{"title":"Telerobotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telerobotics"},{"title":"Optimus (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimus_(robot)"},{"title":"Programming by demonstration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Programming_by_demonstration"},{"title":"Mobile manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_manipulator"},{"title":"FIRST Overdrive - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIRST_Overdrive"},{"title":"Starsky Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starsky_Robotics"},{"title":"Recycle Rush - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recycle_Rush"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about teleoperation robots:

## Definition

Teleoperation (or remote operation) indicates operation of a system or machine at a distance.(no content)Telerobotics is the area of robotics concerned with the control of semi-autonomous robots from a distance, chiefly using television, wireless networks (like Wi-Fi, Bluetooth and the Deep Space Network) or tethered connections.

## Key Characteristics

A telemanipulator (or teleoperator) is a device that is controlled remotely by a human operator.(no content)In simple cases the controlling operator's command actions correspond directly to actions in the device controlled, as for example in a radio-controlled model aircraft or a tethered deep submergence vehicle.

## Applications

Teleoperation robots are used in various fields:

- Industrial machinery is often operated remotely, particularly in hazardous environments. Examples include the construction of the Object Shelter or sarcophagus at Chernobyl after the Chernobyl accident, and removal of debris after hazardous rock slides.

- Remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) are extensively used in hazardous environments (i.e. radioactive environments, contaminated environments, minefields, deep oceans).

- Most space exploration has been conducted with telerobotic space probes. Most space-based astronomy, for example, has been conducted with telerobotic telescopes.

- Mobile manipulators, either autonomous or remote operated, are used in many areas, such as space exploration, military operations, home care and health care.

I've completed a web search on "UAV drone" and found comprehensive information. Here are the key results:

## Definition and Overview

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications. The uses are quite diverse, ranging from:

- **Military Use**: UAVs are used by a broad range of military forces, from Argentina to the US and also by Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIS).
- **Conservation**: ConservationDrones works with NGOs, research organizations, and governments to collect environmental data through drone usage and provides low cost UAVs to these organizations, especially in developing countries, for as little as $2500.
- **Aircraft Maintenance**: Airlines and maintenance, repair, and operations contractors use UAVs for aircraft maintenance, with EasyJet beginning to test UAVs in 2015 for maintaining Airbus A320s.

## Autonomy Levels

The flight of UAVs may operate under remote control by a human operator, as remotely piloted aircraft (RPA), or with various degrees of autonomy, such as autopilot assistance, up to fully autonomous aircraft that have no provision for human intervention.

The search results show that UAVs/drones have become increasingly important across military, commercial, and humanitarian sectors with diverse applications and capabilities.

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle_applications"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Medium-altitude long-endurance UAV - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medium-altitude_long-endurance_UAV"},{"title":"Fiber optic drone - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiber_optic_drone"},{"title":"Gerbera (drone) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerbera_(drone)"},{"title":"Rubicon (UAV unit)","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rubicon_(UAV_unit)"},{"title":"Mugin UAV Mugin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mugin_UAV_Mugin"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicles in the United States military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_the_United_States_military"},{"title":"RAM-2X - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RAM-2X"}]

I've completed a web search on "UAV drone" and found comprehensive information. Here are the key results:

## Definition and Overview

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications. The uses are quite diverse, ranging from:

- **Military Use**: UAVs are used by a broad range of military forces, from Argentina to the US and also by Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIS).
- **Conservation**: ConservationDrones works with NGOs, research organizations, and governments to collect environmental data through drone usage and provides low cost UAVs to these organizations, especially in developing countries, for as little as $2500.
- **Aircraft Maintenance**: Airlines and maintenance, repair, and operations contractors use UAVs for aircraft maintenance, with EasyJet beginning to test UAVs in 2015 for maintaining Airbus A320s.

## Autonomy Levels

The flight of UAVs may operate under remote control by a human operator, as remotely piloted aircraft (RPA), or with various degrees of autonomy, such as autopilot assistance, up to fully autonomous aircraft that have no provision for human intervention.

The search results show that UAVs/drones have become increasingly important across military, commercial, and humanitarian sectors with diverse applications and capabilities.

Web search results for query: "Surveillance"

Links: [{"title":"Surveillance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surveillance"},{"title":"Mass surveillance in the United Kingdom - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_surveillance_in_the_United_Kingdom"},{"title":"Global surveillance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_surveillance"},{"title":"Mass surveillance in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_surveillance_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"List of government mass surveillance projects - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_government_mass_surveillance_projects"},{"title":"Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_Intelligence_Surveillance_Act"},{"title":"Intelligence, surveillance, target acquisition, and reconnaissance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligence,_surveillance,_target_acquisition,_and_reconnaissance"},{"title":"Mass surveillance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_surveillance"},{"title":"Surveillance (2008 film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surveillance_(2008_film)"},{"title":"List of films featuring surveillance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_films_featuring_surveillance"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of surveillance:

## Definition

Surveillance is the systematic observation and monitoring of a person, population, or location, with the purpose of information-gathering, influencing, managing, or directing.

## Uses and Scope

It is widely used by governments for a variety of reasons, such as law enforcement, national security, and information gathering.(no content)Mass surveillance is the intricate surveillance of an entire or a substantial fraction of a population in order to monitor that group of citizens.

## Methods

The vast majority of computer surveillance involves the monitoring of data and traffic on the Internet, with automated Internet surveillance computers sifting through vast amounts of intercepted Internet traffic to identify suspicious activity.

## Concerns

Surveillance can unjustifiably violate people's privacy and is often criticized by civil liberties activists.(no content)Democracies may have laws that seek to restrict governmental and private use of surveillance, whereas authoritarian governments seldom have any domestic restrictions.

## Government Programs

The NSA runs a program known as PRISM, which is a data mining system that gives the United States government direct access to information from technology companies, allowing the government to obtain search history, emails, stored information, live chats, file transfers, and more.

## Mobile Robot Overview

Here are the key findings from the search on mobile robots:

### Definition and Basics

A mobile robot is an automatic machine that is capable of locomotion.(no content)Mobile robots have the capability to move around in their environment and are not fixed to one physical location.(no content)Mobile robotics is usually considered to be a subfield of robotics and information engineering.

### Components

The components of a mobile robot are a controller, sensors, actuators and power system.(no content)The controller is generally a microprocessor, embedded microcontroller or a personal computer (PC).

### Applications

Mobile robots have diverse applications across multiple industries:
- Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years.
- Warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.
- Mobile robots are also found in industrial, military and security settings.

### Research and Development

Mobile robots are also a major focus of current research and almost every major university has one or more labs that focus on mobile robot research.

The search results include information about specific mobile robot examples, like the Khepera robot series used in research and education, and various historical developments in the field of mobile robotics.

Links: [{"title":"Feature (computer vision) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feature_(computer_vision)"},{"title":"Computer vision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_vision"},{"title":"Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conference_on_Computer_Vision_and_Pattern_Recognition"},{"title":"Bag-of-words model in computer vision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bag-of-words_model_in_computer_vision"},{"title":"Category:Computer vision software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Computer_vision_software"},{"title":"Category:All Computer Vision articles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:All_Computer_Vision_articles"},{"title":"Video imprint (computer vision) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_imprint_(computer_vision)"},{"title":"Template talk:Feature detection (computer vision) navbox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_talk:Feature_detection_(computer_vision)_navbox"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category_talk:Computer_vision"},{"title":"Active vision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_vision"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of computer vision:

## Definition and Purpose

Computer vision is the scientific discipline concerned with the theory behind artificial systems that extract information from images.(no content)As an interdisciplinary field, it deals with how computers can be made to gain high-level understanding from digital images or videos, seeking to automate tasks that the human visual system can do.

##Core Tasks and Objectives

Computer vision tasks include methods for acquiring, processing, analyzing, and understanding digital images, and extraction of high-dimensional data from the real world in order to produce numerical or symbolic information.(no content)Understanding in this context signifies the transformation of visual images into descriptions of the world that can elicit appropriate action.

## Key Subdisciplines

Subdisciplines of computer vision include scene reconstruction, object detection, event detection, activity recognition, video tracking, object recognition, 3D pose estimation, learning, indexing, motion estimation, visual servoing, 3D scene modeling, and image restoration.

## Data Types

Image data can take many forms, such as video sequences, views from multiple cameras, multi-dimensional data from a 3D scanner, 3D point clouds from LiDaR sensors, or medical scanning devices.

## Recent Developments

The advancement of Deep Learning techniques has brought further life to the field of computer vision.

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous underwater vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_underwater_vehicle"},{"title":"Category:Underwater robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Underwater_robots"},{"title":"Unmanned underwater vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underwater_robotics"},{"title":"Underwater Dreams - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underwater_Dreams"},{"title":"Nereus (underwater vehicle) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nereus_(underwater_vehicle)"},{"title":"Robot fish - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_fish"},{"title":"SeaPerch - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SeaPerch"},{"title":"Remotely operated underwater vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remotely_operated_underwater_vehicle"},{"title":"Amok (video game) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amok_(video_game)"},{"title":"ROV SuBastian - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ROV_SuBastian"}]

Here's what I found about underwater robots:

## Overview

Unmanned underwater vehicles (UUV), also known as underwater drones, are submersible vehicles that can operate underwater without a human occupant.(no content)These vehicles may be divided into two categories: remotely operated underwater vehicles (ROUVs) and autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs).

## Types of Underwater Robots

**Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs):**
An autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) is a robot that travels underwater without requiring continuous input from an operator.(no content)AUVs are automated and operate independently of direct human input.

**Remotely Operated Vehicles (ROVs):**
ROUVs are remotely controlled by a human operator.(no content)The ROV will be fitted with thrusters, cameras, lights, tether, a frame, and pilot controls to perform basic work. Additional sensors, such as manipulators and sonar, can be fitted as needed for specific tasks.

## Robot Fish

A robot fish is a type of bionic robot that has the shape and locomotion of a living fish. Most robot fish are designed to emulate living fish which use body-caudal fin (BCF) propulsion, and can be divided into three categories: single joint (SJ), multi-joint (MJ) and smart material-based "soft-body" design.

## Applications

The use of uncrewed Underwater Vehicles has risen consistently since they were introduced in the 1960s, and find their most frequent use in scientific research and data collection.(no content)For instance, the REMUS is a three-foot long robot used to clear mines in one square mile within 16 hours. This is much more efficient, as a team of human divers would need upwards of 21 days to perform the same task.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Sensor fusion"

Links: [{"title":"Sensor fusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensor_fusion"},{"title":"Data fusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_fusion"},{"title":"Multi-focus image fusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-focus_image_fusion"},{"title":"MEMS sensor generations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MEMS_sensor_generations"},{"title":"Fusion frame - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fusion_frame"},{"title":"Shimshon Belkin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shimshon_Belkin"}]

## Sensor Fusion

Sensor fusion is a process of combining sensor data or data derived from disparate sources so that the resulting information has less uncertainty than would be possible if these sources were used individually.

### Key Concepts

**Centralized vs. Decentralized Approaches:**
In centralized fusion, the clients simply forward all of the data to a central location where it is correlated and fused, while in decentralized approaches, the clients take full responsibility for fusing the data.

**Sensor Configuration Types:**
- **Redundant Configuration:** Sensors are in redundant configuration if each node delivers independent measures of the same properties, which can be used in error correction when comparing information from multiple nodes.

- **Complementary Configuration:** Complementary configuration occurs when multiple information sources supply different information about the same features, used for fusing information at raw data level within decision-making algorithms.

- **Cooperative Sensor Fusion:** Cooperative sensor fusion uses the information extracted by multiple independent sensors to provide information that would not be available from single sensors.

### Fusion Levels

Data level (or early) fusion aims to fuse raw data from multiple sources at the lowest level of abstraction and is the most common sensor fusion technique in many fields, combining multiple homogeneous sources of sensory data to achieve more accurate and synthetic readings.(no content)In feature level fusion, features are computed on board by each sensing node and then sent to a fusion node to feed the fusion algorithm.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Coordination robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Cognitive robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_robotics"},{"title":"Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics"},{"title":"Human–robot collaboration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–robot_collaboration"},{"title":"Microsoft Robotics Developer Studio - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Robotics_Developer_Studio"},{"title":"Daniela Rus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniela_Rus"},{"title":"Cartesian coordinate robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cartesian_coordinate_robot"},{"title":"Behavior-based robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior-based_robotics"},{"title":"Cobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cobot"},{"title":"Telerobotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telerobotics"},{"title":"Human–robot interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–robot_interaction"}]

Based on the search results for "Coordination robotics," here's what I found:

## Motor Coordination in Robots

Once a robot can coordinate its motors to produce a desired result, the technique of learning by imitation may be used. This is a fundamental capability that enables robots to learn from observing and imitating other agents.

## Multi-Robot Coordination

Coordination in robotics extends to managing multiple robots working together. The focus in this work is on developing simple generic mechanisms that result in coordinated group behavior, either implicitly or explicitly. Researchers like Daniela Rus have made significant contributions in this area; Rus has contributed some of the first multi-robot system algorithms with performance guarantees in distributed robotics, by introducing a control-theoretic optimization approach for adaptive decentralized coordination.

## Human-Robot Coordination

In collaborative settings, agents must decide how to achieve their goals, determine what actions will be done by each agent, and how to coordinate the actions of individual agents and integrate their results. Additionally, social robots need this coordination to perform human-like behaviors.

## Technical Approaches

One notable tool for robotics coordination was the Concurrency and Coordination Runtime (CCR), a .NET Framework-based concurrent library implementation for managing asynchronous parallel tasks, which involves using message-passing and a lightweight services-oriented runtime, Decentralized Software Services (DSS), allowing orchestrating multiple services to achieve complex behaviors.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results for "Coordination robotics," here's what I found:

## Motor Coordination in Robots

Once a robot can coordinate its motors to produce a desired result, the technique of learning by imitation may be used. This is a fundamental capability that enables robots to learn from observing and imitating other agents.

## Multi-Robot Coordination

Coordination in robotics extends to managing multiple robots working together. The focus in this work is on developing simple generic mechanisms that result in coordinated group behavior, either implicitly or explicitly. Researchers like Daniela Rus have made significant contributions in this area; Rus has contributed some of the first multi-robot system algorithms with performance guarantees in distributed robotics, by introducing a control-theoretic optimization approach for adaptive decentralized coordination.

## Human-Robot Coordination

In collaborative settings, agents must decide how to achieve their goals, determine what actions will be done by each agent, and how to coordinate the actions of individual agents and integrate their results. Additionally, social robots need this coordination to perform human-like behaviors.

## Technical Approaches

One notable tool for robotics coordination was the Concurrency and Coordination Runtime (CCR), a .NET Framework-based concurrent library implementation for managing asynchronous parallel tasks, which involves using message-passing and a lightweight services-oriented runtime, Decentralized Software Services (DSS), allowing orchestrating multiple services to achieve complex behaviors.

## Swarm Robotics

Here's an overview of swarm robotics based on the search results:

### Definition and Concept

Swarm robotics applies swarm intelligence to multi-robot collaboration.(no content)Unlike distributed robotic systems in general, swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots.(no content)The approach takes inspiration from nature, such as collective problem solving mechanisms seen in honey bee aggregation.

### Key Principles

Robots in swarm systems are autonomous, do not exploit centralized control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish tasks.(no content)Robots possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities, such as wireless transmission systems like radio frequency or infrared.(no content)Miniaturization is a key factor in swarm robotics, as thousands of small robots can maximize swarm-intelligent behavior through greater interactions.

### History

The phrase "swarm robotics" made its first appearance in 1991, but research grew significantly in the early 2000s.(no content)One of the first major projects was SWARM-BOTS (2001-2005), which demonstrated self-organized teams of robots that cooperate to solve complex tasks with robots taking different roles over time.

### Applications

A promising use of swarm robotics is in search and rescue missions, where swarms of different-sized robots can be sent to places rescue workers cannot reach safely.(no content)Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks demanding cheap designs, such as mining or agricultural shepherding.(no content)Progress has been made in swarm 3D printing for production of large structures where traditional 3D printing cannot be utilized.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Urban Search and Rescue:

## Definition and Purpose

Urban search and rescue (abbreviated as USAR or US&R) is a type of technical rescue operation that involves the location, extrication, and initial medical stabilization of victims trapped in an urban area, namely structural collapse due to natural disasters, war, terrorism or accidents, mines and collapsed trenches.

## Types of Incidents

Urban search-and-rescue is considered a multi-hazard discipline, as it may be needed for a variety of hazards including earthquakes, cyclones, storms and tornadoes, floods, dam failures, technological accidents, terrorist activities, and hazardous materials releases.

## Team Composition

USAR teams bring together, in an integrated response: highly trained personnel from the emergency services along with engineers, medics and search dog pairs, specialised equipment effective communications established methods of command and control logistical support procedures to request international assistance if required under an international search and rescue framework.

## Key Operational Elements

Search involves locating victims of a disaster by using specialized electronic equipment and tools to search for missing or trapped victims, and rescue involves extricating a victim from the location where they are trapped, usually involving removing debris from around the victim.

## United States Organization

After the 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake, seeing the value in having a network of such teams in the United States, FEMA created the National Urban Search and Rescue (US&R) Response System that same year.(no content)The number of teams has expanded to 28 since 1991.

Web search results for query: "LiDAR"

Links: [{"title":"Lidar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidar"},{"title":"Geological structure measurement by LiDAR - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geological_structure_measurement_by_LiDAR"},{"title":"Velodyne Lidar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Velodyne_Lidar"},{"title":"Daniel Lidar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Lidar"},{"title":"Lidar traffic enforcement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidar_traffic_enforcement"},{"title":"Atmospheric lidar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atmospheric_lidar"},{"title":"Radar detector - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radar_detector"},{"title":"Argo AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argo_AI"},{"title":"Moonraker (lunar orbiter) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moonraker_(lunar_orbiter)"},{"title":"Airborne sensor operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airborne_sensor_operator"}]

## LiDAR Overview

LiDAR (an acronym of "light detection and ranging" or "laser imaging, detection, and ranging") is a method for determining ranges by targeting an object or a surface with a laser and measuring the time for the reflected light to return to the receiver.

### How It Works

LiDAR may operate in a fixed direction (e.g., vertical) or it may scan directions, in a special combination of 3D scanning and laser scanning.(no content)The laser receptor calculates the distance by the travelling time between emitting and receiving laser pulses.

### Applications

LiDAR has terrestrial, airborne, and mobile uses and is commonly used to make high-resolution maps, with applications in surveying, geodesy, geomatics, archaeology, geography, geology, geomorphology, seismology, forestry, atmospheric physics, laser guidance, airborne laser swathe mapping (ALSM), and laser altimetry.(no content)It has also been increasingly used in control and navigation for autonomous cars and for the helicopter Ingenuity on its record-setting flights over the terrain of Mars.

### History

The essential concept of lidar was originated by E. H. Synge in 1930, who envisaged the use of powerful searchlights to probe the atmosphere. Under the direction of Malcolm Stitch, the Hughes Aircraft Company introduced the first lidar-like system in 1961, shortly after the invention of the laser.

LiDAR may operate in a fixed direction (e.g., vertical) or it may scan directions, in a special combination of 3D scanning and laser scanning.(no content)The laser receptor calculates the distance by the travelling time between emitting and receiving laser pulses.

### Applications

LiDAR has terrestrial, airborne, and mobile uses and is commonly used to make high-resolution maps, with applications in surveying, geodesy, geomatics, archaeology, geography, geology, geomorphology, seismology, forestry, atmospheric physics, laser guidance, airborne laser swathe mapping (ALSM), and laser altimetry.(no content)It has also been increasingly used in control and navigation for autonomous cars and for the helicopter Ingenuity on its record-setting flights over the terrain of Mars.

### History

The essential concept of lidar was originated by E. H. Synge in 1930, who envisaged the use of powerful searchlights to probe the atmosphere. Under the direction of Malcolm Stitch, the Hughes Aircraft Company introduced the first lidar-like system in 1961, shortly after the invention of the laser.

I've completed a web search for "Path planning robotics". Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

Path planning is the process of computing a continuous path that connects a start configuration and a goal configuration while avoiding collision with known obstacles.

## Real-Time Path Planning

Real-Time Path Planning consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment, including algorithms that continuously take in information from the surroundings and create a plan to avoid obstacles.

## Main Approaches

Several algorithmic approaches are used for path planning:

- **Sampling-Based Algorithms**: Sampling-based algorithms avoid the problem of local minima and solve many problems quite quickly, though they are unable to determine that no path exists but have a probability of failure that decreases to zero as more time is spent.

- **Probabilistic Roadmap (PRM)**: The probabilistic roadmap planner is a motion planning algorithm in robotics that solves the problem of determining a path between a starting configuration and a goal configuration while avoiding collisions.

- **Any-Angle Path Planning**: Any-angle path planning algorithms search for a Euclidean shortest path between two points on a grid map while allowing the turns in the path to have any angle.

- **Grid-Based Algorithms**: At each grid point, the robot is allowed to move to adjacent grid points as long as the line between them is completely contained within free space, and search algorithms like A* are used to find a path from the start to the goal.

## Applications

Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields such as animating digital characters, video games, and robotic surgery.

Links: [{"title":"Distributed control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_control_system"},{"title":"Distributed version control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_version_control"},{"title":"Category:Distributed version control systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Distributed_version_control_systems"},{"title":"Distributed parameter system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_parameter_system"},{"title":"Talk:Distributed control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Distributed_control_system"},{"title":"Decentralised system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decentralised_system"},{"title":"Hierarchical control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_control_system"},{"title":"Asynchronous system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asynchronous_system"},{"title":"Multi-room audio - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-room_audio"},{"title":"Revision Control System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Revision_Control_System"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about Distributed Control Systems:

## Overview

A distributed control system (DCS) is a computerized control system for a process or plant usually with many control loops, in which autonomous controllers are distributed throughout the system, but there is no central operator supervisory control.

## Key Characteristics

The primary advantage of DCS architecture is its reliability. The key attribute of a DCS is its reliability due to the distribution of the control processing around nodes in the system. This mitigates a single processor failure. If a processor fails, it will only affect one section of the plant process, as opposed to a failure of a central computer which would affect the whole process.

Additionally, this distribution of computing power local to the field Input/Output (I/O) connection racks also ensures fast controller processing times by removing possible network and central processing delays.

## Applications

Distributed control systems (DCS) are dedicated systems used in manufacturing processes that are continuous or batch-oriented.(no content)DCS tends to be used on large continuous process plants where high reliability and security is important, and the control room is not necessarily geographically remote.

## System Architecture

DCS systems are organized into multiple hierarchical levels:

Level 0 contains the field devices such as flow and temperature sensors, and final control elements, such as control valves. Level 1 contains the industrialised Input/Output (I/O) modules, and their associated distributed electronic processors. Level 2 contains the supervisory computers, which collect information from processor nodes on the system, and provide the operator control screens. Level 3 is the production control level, which does not directly control the process, but is concerned with monitoring production and monitoring targets. Level 4 is the production scheduling level.

For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Collaborative Multi-Robot Search and Rescue: Planning, Coordination, Perception, and Active Vision". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey

**Key Findings:**
- Extracted and validated **19 technology/methodology triples** from the paper's title and abstract
- All triples properly classified with correct Wikipedia links
- Successfully passed validation with no errors

**Entity Distribution:**
- **Tasks** (4): Search and rescue, Robotic mapping, Surveillance, Urban search and rescue
- **Artifacts** (4): Autonomous robot, Unmanned aerial vehicle, Autonomous underwater vehicle, Mobile robot
- **Concepts** (4): Teleoperation, Multi-agent system, Swarm robotics, Distributed control system
- **Methods** (6): Simultaneous localization and mapping, Active perception, Active vision, Motion planning, Computer vision, Sensor fusion
- **Tools** (1): Lidar

**Key Technologies Identified:**
The survey focuses on multi-robot coordination and perception for SAR operations, with emphasis on:
- Heterogeneous robot types (ground, aerial, underwater, surface vehicles)
- Active perception and vision methods
- Multi-agent system coordination
- Sensor fusion and mapping techniques
- Distributed control approaches

All data has been validated and stored in `triples_output.json`.
